msgSnippet: Simon, I m glad to see you putting energy into helping beginners. I d like to think there is a lot of leverage in having more responsible, skilled programmers
messageBody:
Simon,

I'm glad to see you putting energy into helping beginners. I'd like to think
there is a lot of leverage in having more responsible, skilled programmers
out there. "Thinking in Tests" is a strong name for what is possible with
JUnit. I know for me the "conversion" came when I went from thinking
"feature->implementation" to "feature->test".

I've come to the conclusion that testing, developer testing anyway, is
mostly about design. I think early lessons in developer testing should focus
on coupling, cohesion, and what to do about it, not about equivalence
partitioning. Sadly, design is what Yourdon and Constantine were talking
about 25 years ago and we haven't seemed to make much progress on
consistently achieving good design since then.

Anyway, I would like to see more beginning JUnit materials. I can make sure
they get onto the JUnit.org homepage.

Regards,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute
